name: Katz's Delicatessen
address: 205 E Houston St, New York, NY 10002, USA

reviews.text: Food was decent.

The place was filled with people trying to line up for sandwiches. They had no real system in place and the place was not that clean, maybe it because it was busy . I went to the restroom and when I came back my food was gone from the table and someone else was at my tableâ€¦.  weird.
The food was salt so if you have high blood pressure or have special dietary restrictions you may want to think . This is not the experience you want to rethink.
It was like getting food at a war zone for me the taste was not exceptional it was not worth what I went through to get to the door . Standing in line outside for over 20 minutes.
In summary I have had better sandwiches and service at other places in NYC I would not recommend unless you want the experience and look at pics of famous people.
They do give you a big sandwich but you have to pay
It was 28 dollars and we had corn beef on a hero, beans which were loaded with sugar .
We took ruben with pastrami and classic pastrami. Both were great but if you have to choose one, go for the pastrami
Best. Sandwich. Iâ€™ve. Ever. Had.
Ø®ÙŠØ§Ù„

Read this if you're easily overstimulated & overwhelmed:

Everyone gets a ticket when they walk in (even if you don't order anything) - don't lose this ticket!! You give the ticket to the person at each counter so they can tally up your order total. Before leaving, you stop at the register to pay.

There are 4 counters -
1 (counter closest to the street) - knish, hot dog, soups - this counter isn't really labeled (none of them really are lol). But you'll see the menu for knish, hot dog, soups, etc. listed above the area and there should be someone standing by the grill
2 - meats -- there are numerous meat cutters, you can just pick whichever number you fancy
3 - drinks - underneath the big sign for Dr browns root beer
(Right around this area is a station to get forks/ knives/spoons)
4 (counter furthest back) - latkes, blintzes, desserts, Togo station - you'll see workers with iPad registers. You can order here, have them wrap up your leftovers, or pickup a Togo order.

You have to order each item at its respective station. This requires a bit of planning. I recommend sandwich station
(2) first. Soup, knish, hot dog (1) or drinks (3) have minimal lines and you get your item almost immediately, so l recommend getting these items after your sandwich.

Latkes and blintzes take a bit to make so if you have two people, maybe have one order the blintz/latke while the other orders the sandwich. The sandwich doesn't take long to make, it's just the lines are a bit longer than other stations.

Food was absolutely delicious! Portions are huge!! I split a pastrami sandwich, matza ball soup, knish, latkes (comes with 3 huge latkes + sour cream & apple sauce) and blintzes (comes with 3 cheese blintzes + sour cream, jelly & apple sauce). It was way too much for for the two of us lol. I love latkes & blintzes and wanted to try them here but I don't think I'll order again. They weren't bad, it's just that it was way too much food with everything else. If you're gonna get one thing, definitely get a pastrami sandwich (with extra sauerkraut). Their mustard is out of this world!! The knish is good but I'm pretty sure it's the same as every other knish l've had in NY lol
Pyszne kanapki. Warto czekaÄ‡ w kolejce. Polecam

Itâ€™s just what I imagined. A few recommendations - bring cash. Have your selection decided upon ahead of time - the lines stay long. Donâ€™t lose your ticket! Drinks are in a separate line from the food. So are the sides.

If you have someone with you, have them grab a seat while you order. Tip if you can! The guys work hard to prep orders.

Great experience and Iâ€™m glad I finally made it. The pastrami on rye was my favorite.

This used to be the best pastrami sandwich In the world but the meat is not as juicy as it usually is and is dry. It never tasted like that before. I hope it was an one off. Katz please go back to your old ways I remember going there late at night hammered and now you guys arenâ€™t open late anymore either whatâ€™s going on! The pastrami is dry whatâ€™s going on guys!?

Great pastrami and rye sandwich and matzoh ball soup. A little pricey, but well worth the experience. Spent $68 for two half sandwiches, two matzoh ball soups, two drinks and tip.
Es un clÃ¡sico. Medio lÃ­o pedir todo por separado y encontrar mesa pero con paciencia se logra. La comida un 10!
One of the best sandwiches I've ever had. Next level.
Very good atmosphere and delicious food!

The food was great, the line seemed big at first (started half a block away) but moved really fast, service was great and the atmosphere inside was just line in the movies. The main downside is the constant pressure to eat fast and free your table
every trip to NYC KATZ is gotta be one the firsts list!!!  We order to ship back home too!!  LOVE LOVE LOVE!

Itâ€™s famous for a reason and yes you should wait in the line. Super worth it in my opinion. Our favorite ended up being the â€œKikiâ€ special, iykykâ€¦ our cutter made his favorite, 1/2 brisket 1/2 pastrami, mustard and Rueben dressing on special sides of the bread, melted cheeseâ€¦ chefs kiss.
Still the best pastrami experience! Long line in front of the restaurant but it was worth waiting.
My favorite food when Im on NYC.. Pastrami on rye with Swiss and extra mustard
This was actually very delicious. The meats were very flavorful
Perfect spot for a nice evening out. Everything felt just right.
Great Food Dont forget to walk over to take a picture of the NYSE Wall St Bull.
The food was 10/10 packed with flavor and perfectly done. The vibes are amazing, classic New York energy. A little pricey, but absolutely worth it for the experience.

Overrated, letâ€™s start.

We wanted to enjoy this so much. Walked in and approached the servery to be met with a very aggressive guy just inside, WHAT YA DOING ! Just want a sandwich sir. Take these red tickets and see the server bottom right, ok.

Served by a lovely waitress, now we ordered the famous pastrami and a tuna salad as the wife donâ€™t eat beef. Wow what a massive stack of beef, this sandwich is huge, tucked in and first impressions are salt and nothing else, Iâ€™m thinking heart attack on a plate and Iâ€™m not wrong. Managed to eat 80% of this monster salt incarnation of a beef sandwich. This made me sick the next day the body could just not digest the salt and red meat and Iâ€™m a full on carnivore, medium rare sort of guy.

Looking around this place itâ€™s full of self glorification with pictures of people Iâ€™d never known or seen, we did see one picture of George Forman from probably 30 years ago . The place looks like it needs some serious renovation itâ€™s stuck in 1954 and looks like itâ€™s not been cleaned since. Filthy signs that never get cleaned, this dump is living on its reputation from a bygone era.

In conclusion, absolutely overrated and over priced. Do yourself a favour and donâ€™t waste your money.
Great experience, pretty tasty food. Be prepared to wait a long time.
Terrific pastrami.
Great food and service

Yummy yum full! OMG, I had a full sandwich (Pastrami and Brisket) After I died, I was taken to a new plane, where I weighed twice as much and steps felt eternal. Turns out I was on the W 4th st station waiting on the E train holding a to go Pastrami on Rye. How I got there will always be a mystery. The memory of that sandwich still lives with me though. If you are ready to let go of your inhibitions and experience it yourself, don't be mislead by the line, it moves quick.

The best pastrami sandwich shop.

It's so traditional and famous, but the space is fun to walk into and the sandwiches are fantastic.

The sandwiches are big, but they cut them in half so you can share.

When you order the sandwich, they cut the pastrami for you to try, and it's a little salty at first.

But when you eat the pastrami with the bread spread with mustard on one side, it's not salty at all and it's so delicious.

Be sure to order a pickle to go with it.

Takeout is also available.

I think it was not that satisfying food and service. Here is the order process and review :
1. As soon as you enter, you can see the cutter men. You can tell them what you want to eat except for the side and drinks, they'll make and give the menu to you right away
Here's a tip I found at the expense of... ğŸ¥º
Find someone with a lot of tips in the tip box! As soon as I entered, I ordered the half of pastrami sandwich and matzo soup from the man I saw and he gave me the wrong menu. He gave me only a whole sandwich. When I told him this wasn't the menu I ordered, he just shrugged. I wanted to try the soup!! ğŸ˜­
2. Anyway, if you receive the food, you also get a ticket. You can go to the left counter and order the side and drinks. You should give the ticket to the man there. I had cream soda instead of cola and It' was quite delicious. Try it!
3. Most people left the dishes on the table after finishing it, I gave it to the cleaning staff directly.
4. In case of the card payment, you can pay at the counter on the left of the side and drink corner. Show your ticket to the casher and receive the receipt. And finally show the receipt the person who is in front of the door when you left. If you pay with the cash,  you can go right to the door and show your ticket out and pay
I visited there in the saturday morning, like 9am, and there are many vacant seat. So if you don't like crowded atmosphere, it's better to go for breakfast!

1. Take a ticket from the entrance. This will be your kinda-recepit.
2. Line up at one of where it says â€œCutterâ€. Thatâ€™s where you order and get a sandwich. Ask for pickle if you want one.

Pastrami was great but to have a whole sandwich by oneself, it ends up being somewhat greasy and salty although first 3-4 bites donâ€™t give you such impression.
